title: Syllabus
text:
Term: Fall 2023
Instructor: Isaac Quintanilla Salinas
Email: isaac.qs@csuci.edu
Office Location: BTE 2840
Office Hours:



OH
Course
R Programming
TEA Math/Stat Hour




Day
MW
Tue
Th


Location
BT 1462
LRC
BTE Courtyard


Time
4:30-6:00 PM
10-12 AM
12-1:30 PM



Or by Zoom appointment.
Lecture: Monday/Wednesday 10:00-11:50 AM (Sec 01) or 2:00-3:50 PM (Sec 02) in BT 1462



Critical reasoning using a quantitative and statistical, problem-solving approach to solving real-world problems. Topics include: probability and statistics, sample data, probability and empirical data distributions, sampling techniques, estimation and hypothesis testing, ANOVA, and correlation and regression analysis. Students will use standard statistical software to analyze real-world and simulated data. GenEd: B4




Prepare students for advanced courses in data-management and statistics
Reason both inductively and deductively with quantitative information and data
Use statistical software for complex statistical analysis of real-world and simulated data
Empower students to apply computational and inferential thinking to address real-world problems
Write the results of a statistical study and draw conclusion in reports




This course will use Coursekata, a Canvas-embedded textbook with built-in R functionality.



For this course, we will use R and RStudio. You will have access to them online, but you may download and install them on your computer.

R is a free statistical software program that is available for download at: https://www.r-project.org/.
RStudio provides free and open source tools for your data analysis in R: https://www.rstudio.com/




This course will have two embedded peer educators:

Devin Frost (Sec 01)

Email: devin.frost091@csuci.edu

Amanda Parks (Sec 02)

Email: amanda.parks743@myci.csuci.edu


An EPE is there to help you understand the material and succeed in the course. They will be leading in class assignments. hold special tutoring sessions, and support you in your R programming. These educators are trained with study skills that will set you up with success in college.

Participation is based on short writing assignments conducted in class. There will be no make ups for these writing prompts.



Lab assignments are designed to expand your statistical knowledge. These will be completed in JupyterHub which can be accessed from Canvas. There are approximately 2 lab assignments every week that you can complete during class time. The lab assignment will be due either on Tuesday or Thursday at 11:59 PM following the lab day it was assigned.



Reading assignments are designed to teach you different statistical concepts and R Programming. As the course progresses, many of the concepts build on each other. Therefore, the assignments encourage you to read each chapter in an appropriate amount of time. You must read the chapter and answer the questions by the Sunday night at 11:59 PM. The 2 lowest reading assignments will be dropped.



Starting on Week 2, there will be a weekly quiz every Friday. The quiz will become available for you to take on Canvas at 12AM to 11:59 PM every Friday. The quiz is designed to test whether you recall the material from the previous week. You are expected to complete the quiz with out using any material such as your notes, textbook, or internet. Additionally, you will get 90% of the quiz grade for simply taking the quiz. The remaining 10% is based on getting the question correct. There are a total of 12 quizzes in the semester. The lowest 3 quizzes will be dropped from your class grade. There are no make up quizzes.



There will be three in exams. Exam #1 will on Sept 25, Exam #2 will be on Nov 8, and Exam #3 will be on Dec 6 at 8-10 AM (Sec 01) or 1-3 PM (Sec 02). While the exams are not considered cumulative, the material builds on each other. Developing a strong understanding of the material through out the course is important for your success. At the end of the semester, your lowest exam grade will be replaced by your median average exam grade. This course will operate under a zero-tolerance policy. Talking during the time of the exam, sharing materials, looking at another students’ exam, or not following directions given will be subject to the University’s academic integrity policy.



There will be 3 extra credit opportunities worth a total of 10% of your overall grade. (There are no make-ups for missed extra credit assignments!) More information will be provided on the extra credit assignments on a later date. Information on the extra credit can be found here.




The following outline may be subject to change. Any changes will be announced in class.

Academic Honesty:
Please conduct yourself with honesty and integrity. Do not submit others’ work as your own. For assignments and quizzes that allow you to work with a group, only put your name on what the group submits if you genuinely contributed to the work. Work completely independently on exams, using only the materials that are indicated as allowed. Failure to observe academic honesty results in substantial penalties that can include failing the course.
Disabilities:
If you are a student with a disability requesting reasonable accommodations in this course, you need to contact Disability Accommodations and Support Services (DASS) located on the second floor of Arroyo Hall, via email accommodations@csuci.edu or call 805-437-3331. All requests for reasonable accommodations require registration with DASS in advance of need: https://www.csuci.edu/dass/students/apply-for-services.htm. Faculty, students and DASS will work together regarding classroom accommodations. You are encouraged to discuss approved.
Emergency Procedure Notice to Students:
CSUCI is following guidelines and public orders from the California Department of Public Health and Ventura County Public Health for the COVID-19 pandemic as it pertains to CSUCI students, employees and visitors on the campus. Students are expected to adhere to all health and safety requirements as noted on the University’s Spring 2023 Semester website or they may be subject to removal from the classroom.




The California Faculty Association (the labor union of Lecturers, Professors, Coaches, Counselors, and Librarians across the 23 CSU campuses) is in a difficult contract dispute with California State University management. It is possible that we will call a strike or other work stoppage this term. I promise to promptly inform you of any schedule disruption. Our working conditions are your learning conditions; we seek to protect both. For further information go to www.CFAbargaining.org.

\]

title: Quantifying Errors
text:
Quantifying Total Error
1, 2, 2, 3, 3, 3

Mean: 2.33
Median: 2.5
Mode: 3

title: Quantifying Errors
text:
Add all errors together
\[
\sum^6_{i-1}Y_i -\mathrm{model}
\]

Mean: \(0.02 \approx 0\)
Median: -1
Mode: -4

title: Quantifying Errors
text:
Absolute Value of error
\[
\sum^6_{i-1}|Y_i -\mathrm{model}|
\]

Mean: 4
Median: 4
Mode: 4

title: Quantifying Errors
text:
Sum of Squares
\[
\sum^6_{i-1}(Y_i -\mathrm{model})^2
\]

Mean: 3.3334
Median: 3.5
Mode: 6

DGP is not the same as the previous one, it is transformed due \(\beta_0\). Consider this the NULL DGP.

\hat Y=\hat\beta_0
\]

These are also know as residuals (\(\hat r_i\))

title: Research Design
text:
Complete Survey

https://forms.gle/tYgmpJFk6fzz36r18

title: Research Design
section: What is the purpose of research?
text:
What is the purpose of research?
The purpose of research is to systematically investigate, gather information, analyze data, and draw conclusions to advance knowledge, solve problems, or answer questions.

title: Research Design
text:
Experimental Studies
Experimental studies are research designs in which the researcher deliberately manipulates one or more independent variables to observe their effects on an outcome of interest. These studies are commonly used in scientific and social science research to establish cause-and-effect relationships between variables.

title: Research Design
text:
Examples of Experimental Studies

Randomized-Control Trials

Placebo-Drug Studies

title: Research Design
text:
Observational Studies
Observational studies are research designs in which researchers observe and collect data on individuals or groups without intervening or manipulating any variables. These studies aim to understand and describe the relationships between variables or to analyze the natural occurrence of events or phenomena. Unlike experimental studies, observational studies do not involve the manipulation of independent variables, and they are often used when it is not ethical or practical to conduct experiments.

title: Research Design
text:
Examples of Observational Studies

Cross-Sectional Studies
Longitudinal Studies
Case-Control Studies
Cohort Studies

title: Research Design
text:
Randomness

Randomness refers to the lack of predictability or pattern in a sequence of events or outcomes.


Randomness is often associated with chance and uncertainty.

title: Research Design
text: Random Sampling

title: Research Design
text:
Palmer Penguins

333 Penguins Measured
Collected information on:

Flipper Length
Beak Length
Species
Island
Body Mass

~20 million penguins in Antartica

title: Research Design
text: Flipper Length

title: Research Design
text:
Is there a signal?

Are we seeing differences in penguin species?


Or is it due to random chance?


How can we know?


How about we simulate random samples and conduct a permutation test?

title: Research Design
text:
Permutation Test (Shuffling)
A permutation test, also known as a randomization or re-randomization test, is a statistical method used to assess the significance of an observed statistical result by comparing it to a large number of randomly generated permutations or rearrangements of the data.

title: Research Design
text:
Permutation Test

We will shuffle the outcome of interest, while maintaining the species location.

This generates a simulated data set.

We will create a large number of simulated data sets to get an idea of the distribution.
We will then compare the true data with the simulated data sets to see if they overlap.

title: Research Design
text:
Shuffling Penguins

While maintaining the structure of the data, we will shuffle the flipper length and plot them.
We will repeat the process multiple times
Compare the simulated data with the actual data

title: Research Design
text: Shuffling

text: Side by Side

text: Shuffling 9 Plots

title: Research Design
text: Time Management

title: Data Visualization
text:
Histogram
A histogram is a graphical representation of the distribution or frequency of data points in a dataset. It provides a visual way to understand the shape, central tendency, and spread of a dataset by dividing the data into intervals or bins and showing how many data points fall into each bin.

title: Data Visualization
text:
Histogram R Code

gf_histogram(~bill_length_mm, data = penguins)

title: Data Visualization
text: Histogram

title: Data Visualization
text:
Box Plot
A box plot, also known as a box-and-whisker plot, is a graphical representation of the distribution and key statistical characteristics of a dataset. It provides a visual summary of the data’s central tendency, spread, and potential outliers.

title: Data Visualization
text: Box Plot

title: Data Visualization
text:
Box Plot R Code

gf_boxplot(~bill_length_mm, data = penguins)

title: Data Visualization
text: Box Plot

title: Data Visualization
text:
Categorical Variables


#> $species
#>  [1] Adelie    Gentoo    Chinstrap Chinstrap Gentoo    Gentoo    Gentoo   
#>  [8] Adelie    Adelie    Gentoo    Gentoo    Gentoo    Chinstrap Gentoo   
#> [15] Chinstrap Chinstrap Gentoo    Chinstrap Adelie    Adelie   
#> Levels: Adelie Chinstrap Gentoo

title: Data Visualization
text:
Frequency Tables
A frequency table is a statistical tool used to organize and summarize a set of data by counting the number of times each unique value or category appears within the dataset. It provides a simple and clear way to represent the distribution of data, particularly for categorical or discrete variables.

title: Data Visualization
text:
Relative Frequency
Relative frequency is a statistical concept used to describe the proportion or percentage of times a particular event or outcome occurs relative to the total number of observations or occurrences in a dataset or sample.

title: Data Visualization
text:
Proportional Tables
A proportion table is a type of statistical table used to display the relative frequencies or proportions of different categories within a dataset. It provides a way to represent the distribution of data in terms of percentages or proportions, making it easier to compare and understand the relative sizes of different categories.

title: Data Visualization
text:
Pie Charts
A pie chart is a circular graphical representation used to display data in a way that illustrates the relative proportions or percentages of different categories or components within a whole. Pie charts are particularly useful for showing the composition of a dataset when you want to emphasize the parts of a whole and how they relate to each other.

title: Data Visualization
text:
Pie Charts R Code

penguins |> ggplot(aes(x="", fill = species)) + 
  geom_bar() + 
  coord_polar("y")

title: Data Visualization
text: Pie Charts in R

title: Data Visualization
text:
Bar Charts
A bar chart, also known as a bar graph, is a graphical representation used to display categorical data in a way that visually represents the values or frequencies of different categories by using rectangular bars. Bar charts are particularly effective for comparing and showing the relationships between distinct categories or groups.

title: Data Visualization
text:
Bar Charts R Code

gf_bar(~species, data = penguins)

title: Data Visualization
text: Bar Charts R Code

title: Data Visualization
text:
Explaining Variation

This is the process where we try to reduce the variation with the use of other variables.


Can be thought of as getting it less wrong when taking an educated guess.

Outcome Variables
These are variables we want to study.

Also known as outcome of interest.


Also known as dependent variable.

title: Data Visualization
text:
Explanatory Variables
These are variable that explain the outcome of interest.

Also known as predictor variable.


Also known as independent variable.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Week 3

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Data Distribution
When thinking about data, we know an attribute is allowed to vary. With this variation, some numbers are more likely to be observed than others.

title: Data Generating Process
text: Forest from the trees

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Data

When inspecting data:

Do not focus on one individual data point.
See how data points interact with each other
See what is common
See what is rare

title: Data Generating Process
text:
DGP
The data generation process is understanding how variation from the population is transferred to the data collected.

A population has a mechanism to produce data, understanding this mechanism is essential understanding the data.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
DGP
A populations DGP can be defined with the following characteristics:

The potential outcomes that can be observed when measuring
Each potential outcome will have a probability of being observed

The probability must be between 0 and 1

Sum of all the probabilities of each outcome will add up to 1

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Flipping a Coin
Flipping a coin results in either heads or tail. The probability for heads is 50%

The DGP of flipping a coin is the process of selecting an outcome, given the probability of both options are 50%.

title: Data Generating Process

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Expected Study Time
You should spend 2-3 hours per unit of registered class.
For Math 201, spend 8-12 hours to succeed.

title: Numbers & Data
text: Math Minds

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Population
A population is the entire group that we want to know more about.

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Sample
A sample is a subset of a population that is considered representative.

title: Numbers & Data
text: Sample vs Population

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Experimental Unit
An experimental unit is one individual unit from a sample.

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Data
Data is information from a particular experimental unit. There can be more that one piece of information per experimental unit.

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Data Structure
The structure of the data can be represented in various forms:

A list of long numbers
Table

title: Numbers & Data
text: Tabular Form

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Measurements
Measurements are the processes where we represent an attribute of an experimental unit as either a number or category.

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Quantitative Measurements
Quantitative measurements are data measurements that take a numeric form.

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Qualitative Measurements
Qualitative measurements are data measurements that take a certain category.

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Value
A value is a description (number or category) of a specific attribute of an experimental unit.

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Variable
A variable is the descriptive attribute that we want to obtain from an experimental unit. In terms of a data set, the variable contains all the values of specific attribute in a sample.

title: Numbers & Data
text: Penguin

title: Numbers & Data
text: Penguins

title: Numbers & Data
text: Palmer Penguins

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Prediction
When you are given a large data set, what numbers do you want to know about?
What would these numbers tell you about the data?

title: Welcome!
text:
Math Minds

Math MINDS is open to motivated Channel Islands students enrolled in a B4 Quantitative reasoning course this semester. This FREE transformative program includes:

A $350 scholarship award (payable upon completion of the program requirements)
Four workshops early in the semester to develop your mathematical ability with active learning

Weeks 4 through 8 of the semester

Individualized skill development through a minimum of four one-on-one tutoring sessions with Learning Resource Center tutors

Minimum of two tutoring sessions before Week 6 of the semester
Minimum of two additional tutoring sessions before Week 12 of the semester

A short asynchronous online course about learning mathematics
Four MasterMINDS Group Check-In Meetings

Weeks 9 through 15 of the semester

Support to build long-lasting strength and confidence in your mathematical ability
A chance to make new friends and strengthen your college journey!

title: Data Summarization
text:
Sampling
Sampling is the process of selecting units from a population interest to collect data from.

title: Data Summarization
text:
Sampling
When Sampling you want to maintain these properties:

Representative sample
Large enough sample size

title: Data Summarization
text:
Sampling Example
We want to answer the question, are people happy?

title: Data Summarization
text:
Random Sampling
When sampling, we strive for random sampling

Each unit in the population of interest must have an equal probability of being selected for the study.
This ensures a representative population

title: Data Summarization
text:
Independent Sampling
In addition to random sampling, we strive to make sure each unit is independent from each other.

The probability of UNIT A being sampled will not affect the probability of UNIT B to be sampled.

title: Data Summarization
text:
Sampling Variation

Random samples may vary from the population of interest.
Due to randomness, samples many not look the or biased.
However, this is to be expected as because the sample will not be biased in one way or another.
Samples are then considered unbiased as long as experimental units were collected randomly.

title: Data Summarization
text: Data Structure

title: Data Summarization
text:
Data
A data set can be manipulated in ways to make it easier to process:

filter(): allows you to remove rows that do not satisfy a certain condition
select(): select to view certain variables
mutate(): add a new variable to the data set based on a set of instructions

title: Data Summarization
text:
Selecting a Variable
I am interested in viewing species, island, and body_mass_g in my data set:

select(penguins, species, island, body_mass_g)

#> # A tibble: 344 × 3
#>    species island    body_mass_g
#>    <fct>   <fct>           <int>
#>  1 Adelie  Torgersen        3750
#>  2 Adelie  Torgersen        3800
#>  3 Adelie  Torgersen        3250
#>  4 Adelie  Torgersen          NA
#>  5 Adelie  Torgersen        3450
#>  6 Adelie  Torgersen        3650
#>  7 Adelie  Torgersen        3625
#>  8 Adelie  Torgersen        4675
#>  9 Adelie  Torgersen        3475
#> 10 Adelie  Torgersen        4250
#> # ℹ 334 more rows

title: Data Summarization
text:
Filtering a Data Set
I am only interested in looking at the penguins with a body mass bigger than 4000 g:

penguins_over_4000 <- filter(penguins, body_mass_g > 4000)
select(penguins_over_4000, species, island, body_mass_g)

#> # A tibble: 172 × 3
#>    species island    body_mass_g
#>    <fct>   <fct>           <int>
#>  1 Adelie  Torgersen        4675
#>  2 Adelie  Torgersen        4250
#>  3 Adelie  Torgersen        4400
#>  4 Adelie  Torgersen        4500
#>  5 Adelie  Torgersen        4200
#>  6 Adelie  Dream            4150
#>  7 Adelie  Dream            4650
#>  8 Adelie  Dream            4400
#>  9 Adelie  Dream            4600
#> 10 Adelie  Dream            4150
#> # ℹ 162 more rows

Data Manipulation

OR
Data must be formatted in a way for analysis (computer requirements).

title: Data Summarization
text: Missing Data

title: Data Summarization
text:
Handling Missing Data
How do we handle missing data?

Remove the experimental unit
Take and educated guess what it is

Replace with mean
Single Imputation
Multiple Imputation

title: Data Summarization
text:
Handling Missing Data
For this class, we will remove the entire experimental unit.

# Obtaining the number of rows
nrow(penguins)

#> [1] 344

# Removing missing cases
penguins_missing_removed <- drop_na(penguins)
nrow(penguins_missing_removed)

#> [1] 333

title: Summarizing Data
text:
Summary Statistics
Summary statistics are used to describe the distribution of data.

title: Summarizing Data
text:
Central Tendency
Central tendency is a statistical concept that refers to the central or typical value around which a set of data points tends to cluster. It is used to summarize and describe a data set by identifying a single representative value that provides insights into the data’s overall characteristics.

title: Summarizing Data
text:
Variation
Variation in statistics refers to the extent to which data points in a dataset deviate or differ from a central tendency measure. Understanding variation is crucial for making informed decisions, drawing meaningful conclusions, and assessing the reliability of statistical analyses.

title: Summarizing Data
text:
Minimum
The minimum (min) is the smallest value in the data.

title: Summarizing Data
text:
Maximum
The maximum (max) is the largest value in the data.

title: Summarizing Data
text:
Quartiles

Quartiles are three values (Q1, Q2, Q3) that divides the data into four subsets.

title: Summarizing Data
text:
Q1
Q1 is the value signifying that a quarter of the data is lower than it.

title: Summarizing Data
text:
Q2 - Median
Q2 is the value signifying that half of the data is below it.

The median also represents the central tendency of the data.

title: Summarizing Data
text:
Q3
Q3 is the value signifying that 3 quarters of the data is below it.

title: Summarizing Data
text:
Interquartile Range

\[
IQR = Q_3 - Q_1
\]

title: Summarizing Data
text:
Range

\[
R = \mathrm{max} - \mathrm{min}
\]

title: Summarizing Data
text:
How to identify the data?

Sort the data
ID Max and Min
Find the amount of data the makes a quarter:

\(K=N/4\)

Create 4 groups using the sorted data

group by data size
If \(K\) has a decimal, the \(Kth\) value is quartile of each group.

title: Summarizing Data
text:
Mean
Describe how you will find the mean of these numbers:


#> [1] 14  7 12 17 12

title: Summarizing Data
text:
Mean
The mean is another measurement for central tendency.
\[
\bar X = \frac{1}{n}\sum^n_{i=1}X_i
\]

\(n\): total data points
\(X_i\): data points
\(i\): indexing data
\(\sum\): add all from first (bottom) to last (up)

title: Summarizing Data
text: Variance

title: Summarizing Data
text:
Variance
The variance is a measurement on the average squared distance the data points are from the central tendency.
\[
s^2 = \frac{1}{n}\sum^n_{i=1}(X_i-\bar X)^2
\]

title: Summarizing Data
text:
Standard Deviation
The standard deviation is a measurement on the average distance the data points are from the central tendency.
\[
s=\sqrt{s^2}
\]

title: Summarizing Data
text:
Histogram
A histogram is a graphical representation of the distribution or frequency of data points in a dataset. It provides a visual way to understand the shape, central tendency, and spread of a dataset by dividing the data into intervals or bins and showing how many data points fall into each bin.

title: Summarizing Data
text:
Histogram R Code

gf_histogram(~bill_length_mm, data = penguins)

title: Summarizing Data
text: Histogram

title: Summarizing Data
text:
Box Plot
A box plot, also known as a box-and-whisker plot, is a graphical representation of the distribution and key statistical characteristics of a dataset. It provides a visual summary of the data’s central tendency, spread, and potential outliers.

title: Summarizing Data
text: Box Plot

title: Summarizing Data
text:
Box Plot R Code

gf_boxplot(~bill_length_mm, data = penguins)

title: Summarizing Data
text: Box Plot
